segments.text: Might as well get the lights back on.
Follow.
You know, I've been looking at my watch all the time.
I have to keep track of the length of the tape.
It's got a ring, but it doesn't do so.
Did you get viewing before you died?
No, I did not.
And, you know, his brother taught at A.D.
He's here down the hall.
He is.
John?
No, his brother, who was a historian.
I didn't know about that.
First series of questions, this will follow really a biographical filing chronologically in format.
First series of questions concern how you developed an interest in oceanography and what led you to oceanography.
And so, would you briefly discuss your career as it leads up to your meeting with Francis Shepherd?
That's pretty easy.
I lived in Dallas and Fort Worth, and it was convenient for the first couple years to go to North Texas Agricultural College.
I was pretty good in math in high school, so I thought I'd be an electrical engineer.
And so I took the first two years of electrical engineering courses, and that's all I was taught at NTAC.
And I had time for a couple of electives, so I took historical geology and physical geology from one of the math instructors.
His name was Shirley Lynch, who later went to A&M.
And I got quite a bit interested in the geology, so I thought I'd then combine the electrical engineering and the geology.
The only way I could think of combining it was as mining engineering.
So I went to University of Illinois.
on Lynch's recommendation.
And, of course, I wasn't funded or anything.
And so normally people who didn't have much money in those days would get a summer job to make enough money to pay tuition, books, and so forth, and get other jobs when they went there.
Several of us had worked at the World's Fairs, say, in Chicago in 1934 and in San Diego in 19...
35, mainly because World Fairs were places of new employment, and therefore they're a new job.
So we earned enough money then to work to go to school the next year.
So anyway, a couple of us worked in San Diego, then rode the freights and the trike and so forth to Urbana, Illinois.
And the first job that's necessary is to get one
that provides food, and waiting tables, and busing, and so forth.
The next point is to get a job that provides money.
And I had done drafting before, so I got a job with Francis Shepherd at that time, drafting, making maps.
And then, of course, I took mining engineering courses and more geology.
And it became evident after I'd been down a couple coal mines that geology was more interesting, straight geology.
So I switched to straight geology for the bachelor's degree.
And then about that time, Shepard and I started on a big map of California.
And I spent the summer of 1936 in Washington.
at the coast within the coast genetic survey making large-scale maps that later had to be reduced to a common scale and that increased the interest of course in oceanography and then shepherd
had a $10,000 grant that provided for a year of ship time at Scripps and other things.
And so alternate semesters, we'd go from University of Illinois to Scripps.
And so then that providedat that time, then I decided to go to oceanography all the way to marine geology.
Those trips provided an opportunity for master's degrees and doctor's degrees for both Robert Dietz and me.
So we were in the mainstream then of them.
This is a check of tape recorder number two.
The break in the tape is due to a switch in the tape recorder after one seemingly malfunctioned.
Can we start over again?
No, it's all right.
It can be made out.
It's not any problem with that, with what we've done.
I just don't want to take a chance on it getting progressively worse as we go through.
It seems to be getting worse, yeah.
The spindle was driving at too rapid a rate of speed, but this one seems to be moving more slowly.
What sort of man was Francis Shepard?
What was he like when you met him, and what did he do to inspire you to enter oceanography?
Well, he was a
The shepherd, when I first met him, was probably 38 or thereabouts, at least as I recall.
And he was very energetic.
He was motivated by research.
And I'd never met somebody who had been motivated by research before, because at North Texas Agricultural College, the people were mainly interested in teaching and not research.
And it's just a little bit of a different world, different interests, and so forth.
The amount of effort that one will spend to find out, to learn something, was surprising to me.
Though I had tried something like that once before, just and so forth.
And I was much impressed by it.
devotion to marine geology that he used, and the interest of other people in what he was doing.
What about Robert Dietz?
He and I were students at the same level, and Dietz was a very good fundamental thinker, interested in the basics of things.
I was sort of more interested in the
a slightly different approach, more in seeing what the distribution of things were and making deductions from that.
We made a good team.
We worked together for three or four years, together aboard the ship and also as roommates in Illinois.
We actually stayed at the Shepherd's Attic, in the Shepherd's Attic, by the way, for two years, I guess.
When you arrived at Scripps,
doing that first summer.
How large was it?
Well, it had seven professors.
There was just one student, John Lyman, if I remember rightly.
There were a few other people who were there for part of the time, but getting their degrees, I think, at other places.
But the seven professors was really pretty small.
It was headed by...
a Norwegian, Harold Sverdip.

And Fleming was there, and Johnson, both of whom collaborated with Sverdip on the book called The Oceans, which really didn't take a lot of time, but it was quite a fundamental contribution to the knowledge of the ocean.
Other people who were there were Zoe Bell, a bacteriologist, and Chambers, a meteorologist,
McEwen, a physical oceanographer.
I think those are the ones.
What was your reaction to your first time at sea?
Did it convince you more to be an oceanographer?
Yes, I guess the first time at sea was aboard DW Scripps.
That ship had just been bought by Scripps Institution.
It was a schooner.
The topmasts were taken off and part of the bow spread.
The mainsail boom was hoisted to make room for a winch.
And the first sailing was from San Diego to Catalina Island.
It was sort of a show-and-tell cruise.
Now I would not expect very much to come of it, and nothing did.
It was taking several people out.
out in the ocean just to demonstrate the new ship.
But I'd had quite a bit of small boat experience before that with Shepard taking soundings in the La Jolla Canyons and in other places.
I wasn't seasick.
When did you first meet Roger Revelle?
probably 1938, because I went to Scripps as a shepherd the first time in about the middle of 1937, and Ravel was in Norway at that time, finishing out a year after he got his doctor's degree.
And I was well impressed with Roger Ravel, and still as a broad thinker.
When you're
37, 38, what sort of direction do you think your career is going to take?
What sort of interest do you think you're going to pursue in oceanography?
Well, it was clear that it was going to be marine geology because my basic training was in geology.
And that has to be the case for anyone successful in oceanography, not to be...
not to be divided completely amongst all the fields, but to concentrate in one of the fields and know enough about the other fields in order to operate successfully in interdisciplinary fields.
And as a matter of fact, a year aboard the sailing ship was very good in that connection because people on sailing ships learned to live with the sea instead of in spite of the sea.
In fact, that probably is the chief reason why many nations have square-rigger sailing ships as...
as training ships for at least part of their midshipmen to be.
And we're living with the ocean and close to it.
You have a better understanding of the physical oceanography and the meteorology and the biology and the rest of it.
And that's where we're from.
Did you intend to make an academic career, that is, teach from the very beginning?
Well, you know, these are questions that I probably never asked myself.
And as a matter of fact, it had been only a couple years before that I changed from electrical engineering to mining engineering to geology to marine geology.
So this means that anything I thought about what I'd do 10 years later wouldn't have much bearing.
But at that time, of course, marine geology wasn't really a separate science.
There were no, there really was only one course for us on how to talk, and that was by Shepherd at Illinois.
But it would have been, should have been, would have been clear to me that there was, at that time, there was no other avenue for working in that than being a professor.
And as a matter of fact, in 1938, after I got to know Roger Revelle quite well, he advised me against going into the field.
wisely enough, because he knew there weren't enough jobs in it.
There weren't at that time.
It was only after World War II that the Navy realized that it had to know something about the ocean.
So basically, that's what started the trend in increasing size in marine geology, size of profession.
Now, your first job, though, in 41, is that of teaching geology, is it not?
No, the first job in 1971 was making electrical earth resistivity surveys looking for groundwater in Illinois.
And I held that.
That was from the time of Dr. June, 71, in June, 41, to...
February of 43.
The problem there was that the Navy really didn't know much about the ocean at first.
And work was being done through Scripps at what was called the University of California Division of War Research, which was in San Diego.
Shepard was there.
Ravel started there.
Fleming was there.
And others whom I knew well.
Johnson was there.
And other people from other places.
Well, what happened was that

that the first of the work that was done there was recognition of the effect of bottom sediments on the character of anti-submarine sonar searches, and then later pro-submarine devices, pro-submarine strategy and tactics, more or less.
Excuse me.
Now, this had come about because
Shepard and I had made a map of theI'd better say it another wayShepard had made maps of the distribution of bottom sediments on the East Coast while I was still an undergraduate.
And I drew them up into patterns of bottom sediments.
And then later on, when I was at Scripps with Shepard, then we together made bottom sediment charts of that region.
It became evident that

in acoustic warfare that acoustic ranges were very large very long over sand bottom because the sound bounced from one point of contact in long hops might have a range of three or four thousand yards whereas over mud the mud absorbed the sound about like deep water would and so the ranges were short maybe only a thousand yards over rock bottoms there's so much reverberation that the
Submarines couldn't easily be distinguished from rocky bottoms, so at first there was a great effort bombing rock outcrops from the bottom.
And so when that became known, then it was desirable to make bottom sediment charts of the Japan region and finally the whole Asian region.
So that's what we were doing.
Now, what had happened was that Shepard had started that and then had to make a trip to Hawaii for another acoustic problem.
And so he sent a telegram to me to Illinois saying, come with or without permission.
So I did the best I could for that anyway and came out right away then.
And then worked in the field of marine geology for the Navy.
And I take it that's between 43 and 45?
That's right.
It ended with the end of the war.
It should.
And then in 45, what did you do?
Well, I knew that I wanted to stay in the field of marine geology, oceanography, so I went to University of Southern California.
And on the visit there, I was given an offer for joining the department as an assistant
I was just trying to think of the salary there.
I think it was $2,800 a year or something like that.
The first job, the one at the Illinois Geological Survey, was $2,100, and I thought that was quite a bit compared to the $300 or $400 that I'd been earning as a graduate student.
Well, is it at the University of Southern California now?
Let me phrase it this way.
What's the next direction that your career takes in terms of research?
Well, soon after I started teaching at the University of Southern California, actually about three months after I got there,

I had a phone call from a geological survey saying that they were given the responsibility of finding out something about the radioactivity and the size of the hole that was going to be made at Bikini in the bomb tests of 1948.
And so the information, the telegram, was capped in such a way that it seemed worthwhile to the University of Southern California to allow me to go, so they gave me a leave absence for that.
It was about six months.
the head of the department, Thomas Clements, took over my teaching as well as his own.
And then I went on that.
And that, of course, was a good time in marine geology and oceanography altogether, because for the first time, the oceanographers had enough ships.
There were a lot of ships at Bikini.
They weren't operating very well, mostly, for part of the time.
In fact, I had
two minesweepers to take samples and soundings in the lagoons of Bikini and Inuitok, Ronzalap and Rongarik, four atolls there, two were controls, Ronzalap, Rongarik.
Bikini was the bomb test area, and Inuitok was downwind, and that made it a safety problem.
So with the
number of ships that were available, then oceanographers in all fields were able to do a lot of work in the Marshall Islands more intensely than they'd ever been able to do anyplace before.
So this was a turning point for many people in oceanography.
It was for me, I'd say.
So I was quite happy continuing then in the oceanography, using teaching as a mechanism.
Next, there was a call from the Navy.
from the Geological Survey also for the Persian Gulf.
The Navy had wanted to set up a hydrographic office.
Hydrography before had been the matter of writing soundings on charts.
They didn't really have any oceanography, so they'd made noise about wanting to do oceanography, so the Navy gave them the job.
of doing oceanography in the Persian Gulf, and they weren't ready.
So they asked me to take charge of it.
I brought two students with me, one of whom, Robert Dill, is still in the business.
He's director of Virgin Islands Laboratory.
And so we made a rather thorough study in the short time available.
It was only two weeks of ship time in August of 1948.
So that, of course, was it.
a different kind of marine geology, but one like Bikini that could make ties between biological oceanography and physical oceanography with the marine geology.
And then, did you go out to the Persian Gulf?
Yeah, during the summer times it didn't interfere with the teaching.
And what new interest in oceanography in terms of, what direction is your career taking?

Well, it was clear from Bikini and the Persian Gulf that there was a lot of interest in sedimentation, because geologists really hadn'tmarine geologists really hadn't done very much in marine sediments after the Challenger expedition.
In fact, as far as I know, I was the first one to make any systematic measurements of water content along the length of cores, as simple as that, for example.

And then the close connection with the biology means that the organisms, both plants and animals that have calcareous skeletons, were directly associated with the sediments that they produced in both Bikini and the Persian Gulf.
At the same time, of course, I was interested in those.
I continued some work off Southern California, which was really
a continuation of the kind of work that I've done as a doctor's dissertation with Shepard, working with basin sediments.
And there, the organic matter was the main connection with the marine geology sediments.
And what did your work with sediments demonstrate?

from the viewpoint of modern sedimentologists, it demonstrated that there isn't much point in making general grain size measurements where grain size is a function of contribution by biological materials and not a function of distance or transportation.
But more important than that, I got interested in the biogeochemistry, where
we could trace the depth decrease of organic matter in the sediments.
And that, of course, meant that we had to know something about the distribution of carbon and nitrogen in the sediments.
It became clear that only part of the nitrogen was present as organic matter.
So we tried various things.
At the University of Southern California, there was a man named Rittenberg, Sidney Rittenberg, who had been at...
at Scripps as a bacteriologist, and I had several projects, one of which funded a chemist getting his doctorate degree there.
So that meant that we could make close ties between geology, biology, and bacteriology.
That meant that we could take a stratigraphic approach to the distribution of organic matter and see what happened over the space of time as the sediments accumulated at a very slow rate.
We found, for example, we did, among other things, the depth distribution of amino acids
This showed that only about a fifth of the total nitrogen was in amino acids, so where is the rest?

We also then worked on amino sugars and on ordinary sugars and carbohydrates and depth distribution of petroleum compounds or compounds that are closely related to petroleum, ones who are classified as naphthenes and aromatics and so forth.
and worked on gases in the sediments, their origins and so forth.
But in the techniques, I think we worked at that time pretty well, pretty thoroughly with the techniques that were available, techniques up to about 1960.
And in 1960, I put together a book called The Sea Off Southern California to summarize what had been done there in the sediments.
And I had in mind
making a change because I thought we were at the point of diminishing returns for the techniques then available for application to the marine sediments.
And after writing the book, I went to work on the Dead Sea just to learn how salt was deposited.
That also was to enable me to keep my sticky fingers off the manuscript for all the books being printed.
And then when I came back, I stayed another year and decided to change oceans and fields and came to Woods Hole.
changed oceans, and then changed entirely from sediments, almost entirely from sediments to geophysics.
Okay, and your geophysics work.
What were the first things you began to experiment with in geophysics?
Well, what happened at that time was that the, after I'd taken the job at Woods Hole, the geological survey asked me to start a program for them on the
on marine geology.

I talked a lot before with the geological survey in previous years, previous directors, but they were always afraid of the high cost simply because one day of ship time would pay for maybe the whole summer for one geologist out in the field, field expenses.
So they're slow at coming in.
I told them that I'd accepted the job at Woods Hole and couldn't do that.
Suggested that they pay for the
They provide the funds for me to do the work I wanted to do on the coast and send six of their people then to be trained in marine geology and later to make their own way.
So this then resulted in year-to-year work for about six or seven years for the study of the Atlantic continental shelf and slope, mainly the shelf.
And at the end of six or seven years,

The people then had learned how to do the work and wanted to make their own image, and now they have a separate organization, which is pretty large, about 90 people, I think, because the direction of the federal funds is going for energy.
When we came to the coast, the major thing to do was to learn something about the sediments on the surface.
the rocks of the shelf, the structure of the rocks at depth, and then other things like the relationships of the biology to the sediments and the effect of the shelf and slope on the currents.
So this was a probe, multiple-faceted probe, into general oceanography.

most obvious way to learn about the rocks at depth was to do seismic reflection continuous seismic reflection profiling the woods hold had a lot of experience in that before so had lamont head experience the but they were busy with other things so this method we could take a fundamental look at the problem of seismic work and start a new
a new approach, not necessarily following the ways that had been done traditionally.
So the first thing we did then was to look into the problems of seismic reflection, where basically there are several.
One is the source, sound source.
Another is the sound detection, reflection, to detect the echoes reflected back from the inner layers within the bottom.
Neither is the processing of that sound.
Neither is the recording of it.
We started with the recording, I guess, because...
